oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Madonna and Child and Maria Medallion stained glass windows 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: B & W photograph of Mother Mary Magdalena and Reverend Bertrand Fay standing by the Madonna and Child and the Maria Medallion windows which grace the main entrance lobby of the Administration Building on the Maria College Campus, Albany, New York. Each were part of a large stained glass window installed in 1885 above the altar in the Chapel of the original Sisters of Mercy Motherhouse, Rensselaer, New York, the first such convent of the Sisters of Mercy in upstate New York. When the convent was demolished in 1964, these windows were bequeathed to the College by the Sisters of Mercy, sponsors of the College, and encased in a marble wall opening in the main lobby when the second addition was dedicated in 1967. Most recently, the windows were strengthened and restored to their natural beauty by nationally known artesian Joseph A. Savio of All in Glass Studio in Castleton, New York, a meticulous and rewarding project that took one year to complete. The creator of these windows, and where they came from, remain a total mystery, as this is the only piece of history not recorded in the Mercy community archives.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wilder
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Catholic universities and colleges

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maria College Seal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: B & W photograph of the plaque bearing the seal of Maria College and the name of the President of the College from 1968 to 1977, Sister Mary Berchmans Mahoney. The seal combines a series of symbols characterizing the purpose, not only of the college, but also of the Sisters of Mercy. The name "Maria" honors our Lady of Mercy, patroness of the Sisters. The college was chartered by the University of the State of New York in 1958. An open book, the heraldic indication of a college, occupies the center field of the seal. On the left is a shield with red and gold bars topped with a maltese cross. This shield connotes Mercy, the essence of all Divine attributes and the distinctive feature of the humanitarian objectives undertaken by the Foundress of the Sisters of Mercy. The Chi-Rho on the right represents the Christocentric training, the core of the college curriculum. The crown at the top center is a tribute to the patroness of Maria College, the Queen of Heaven. A cross reaching from crown to book symbolizes the far-reaching principles permeating all phases of Maria College life. Mother Catherine McAuley, Founder of the Community, is quoted: "The Divine Lord is present in our midst to aid us in every difficulty, to enable us to surmount every obstacle on our way to His kingdom."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Catholic universities and colleges; Religious articles

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Madonna and Child and Maria Medallion stained glass windows 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Stained glass windows of the Madonna and Child and the Maria Medallion which grace the main entrance lobby of the Administration Building on the Maria College Campus, Albany, New York. Each were part of a large stained glass window installed in 1885 above the altar in the Chapel of the original Sisters of Mercy Motherhouse, Rensselaer, New York, the first such convent of the Sisters of Mercy in upstate New York. When the convent was demolished in 1964, these windows were bequeathed to the College by the Sisters of Mercy, sponsors of the College, and encased in a marble wall opening in the main lobby when the second addition was dedicated in 1967. Most recently, the windows were strengthened and restored to their natural beauty by a nationally known artesian Joseph A. Savio of All in Glass Studio in Castleton, New York, a meticulous and rewarding project that took one year to complete. The creator of these windows, and where they came from, remain a total mystery, as this is the only piece of history not recorded in the Mercy community archives. (Photography by Elizabeth R. Bouchard.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Catholic universities and colleges
Catholicism; Sisters of Mercy; Albany Diocese

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Marian Hall 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Marian Hall, the former Monastery of the Immaculate Conception, is located at 714 New Scotland Avenue, Albany, NY, on the Maria College campus. It was completed in 1929 for the convent of the Dominican nuns, a cloistered Order of Preachers originally established in France. A group of sisters came to the United States in 1880, first settling in Newark, NJ. The Dominican Sisters came to Albany in November 1915 at the invitation of Reverend Thomas Cusack, Bishop of the Diocese. Reverend Mother Mary Emmanuel as Superior came from Detroit to establish the order locally, along with Mother Mary Theresa (who became head of the local order when Mother Mary Emmanuel passed), Sister Mary of the Holy Ghost, Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist, Sister Mary Agnes and two lay Sisters, Sister Mary Aloysius and Sister Mary of the Immaculate Conception. Upon their arrival, the sisters stayed with the Sacred Heart nuns on Kenwood Avenue until a convent was prepared for them on State Street, across from the Capitol. When the building was condemned shortly afterward, they moved to 112 Washington Avenue, where they resided until completion of the convent in September 1929, when it was also open to the public. One unique feature of the structure was the large double chapel, which provided an area on one side for the public to worship, and another chapel behind the altar for the cloistered nuns. These sisters were in constant prayer before the Blessed Sacrement, their order having the rule of perpetual adoration. The architectural style is Gothic, designed along lines similar to old French abbeys. The design was prepared by Gander, Gander and Gander Architects. There is an enclosed courtyard as well as sheltered walkways in the center of the building. The Gander brothers donated the monastery bells. The property had been purchased by Reverend Edmund Gibbons, who later became Bishop, using a donation from a benefactress of the Diocese. This historical information was taken from the Evangelist newspaper, Friday, 9-25-29, pages 1-2, and Sunday, 9-27-29, pages 1-2. Thirty years later, an interview was granted to the Times Union newspaper by Mother Mary Aquinas, O. P., the Mother Prioress of the Monastery. The story appeared in the Sunday edition, 5-31-59, pages E-1, 5. Marian Hall now houses faculty offices and classrooms for nursing students. (Photography by Elizabeth R. Bouchard.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bouchard, Elizabeth R.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Catholic universities and colleges

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1991-03-08 letter to Sister Laureen Fitzgerald
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a thank-you note from Maureen O'Sullivan Cushing to Sister Laureen Fitzgerald, President of Maria College, thanking her for sending a clipping to Maureen and her husband, trustee James Sullivan.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: O'Sullivan, Maureen, 1911-1998;
